title: Which one of these is correct in French: 'C'est à moi', 'C'est la mienne', or both? - Quora

response.answer_text: Both are correct. “C'est la mienne/le mien” is descriptive and somewhat carries an implication that the object has belonged to you for a while. For example “- C'est la voiture de ta mère ? - Non, c'est la mienne.” (Is it your mother's car? No, it's mine) “C'est à moi” is more informal and also more emotional (typically showing pride, or greed). Also, it is often use to appropriate something whose owner is not clear. You could imagine it being used by kids fighting over a toy, robbers fighting over the loot, or a billionaire bragging in front of his palace and 20 luxury cars (“Tout ça, c'est à moi !”). But really, I'm deliberately highlighting the specific cases where they are not really interchangeable to show the nuance. For most purposes, they are interchangeable.

To add a footnote to the nice responses already given, “C'est la mienne” uses the possessive pronoun mien/mienne and so gives a sense of this one is mine (…but that one is yours, “c'est la tienne” etc). “C'est à moi” as someone pointed out already can sound awfully egotistical, as the grammar itself suggests: it's all about me, less about the object. The expression uses the tonic or stress pronoun “moi”. This thing belongs to me, is “for” me, is all mine. There's no hint that it could be yours or that there's another one like it that is yours.
